title-group.article-title: Vibration absorbers for simply supported beams subjected to constant moving loads

article-meta.aff: Department of Industrial and Mechanical Engineering, Lebanese American University, Lebanon

author-notes.corresp: Jimmy S Issa, Department of Industrial and Mechanical Engineering, Lebanese American University, PO Box 36, Byblos, Lebanon. Email: jimmy.issa@lau.edu.lb

abstract.p: Vibration suppression in simply supported beams traversed by constant moving loads is explored using linear vibration absorbers. Assuming the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory, the beam is modeled using its first ten modes. The problem is formulated in terms of dimensionless parameters to render the results generic which are obtained for a range of the beam modal damping ratios and the system mass ratio. The objective is to minimize the maximum beam displacement for all load speeds. It is shown that the optimal absorber is an undamped absorber which should be attached at a fixed location irrespective of the modal damping or mass ratios. The optimal stiffness ratio is calculated numerically and a convenient analytical expression is obtained by curve fitting the numerical results to a second-order polynomial. The maximum error between the analytical model and the numerical solution is found to be negligible. The results are validated through comparison with a numerical example which was considered in the literature.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The vibration of bridges or railway tracks due to moving vehicles or trains have been extensively studied and hence a large number of publications can be found on this topic. The simplest bridge model is that of a simply supported beam assuming either the Euler–Bernoulli or the Timoshenko beam theory. As for the moving vehicle, it is modeled as a dynamic system with several degrees of freedom, and when ignoring its dynamic effects, it is simply modeled as a moving mass. Moghaddas et al.1 proposed a finite element approach for the dynamic analysis of beams traversed by a moving vehicle. The latter is modeled with six degrees of freedom which include its pitch effect. The time-dependent stiffness, damping and forcing matrices are carefully updated and the problem is solved numerically using the Newmark-β method. The results were validated through comparison with previously published works. Ziaei-Rad et al.2 carried out the dynamic analysis of a beam under uniformly distributed moving masses using the discrete element technique. It is shown that the solution converges with the increasing of the element numbers. The accuracy of this technique was validated through comparison with the finite difference and finite element methods (FEM). In terms of computational efforts, the method proved to be an order of magnitude cheaper than the FEM. When the vehicle mass is too small compared to the bridge's mass, it can be simply modeled as a constant moving load. A detailed comprehensive study of the dynamic analysis of beams subjected to several types of moving loads can be found in the book by Frýba.3 The closed-form displacement of a beam with general boundary conditions under a moving force was derived by Abu Hilal and Zibdeh4 using the classical modal superposition method. Greco and Santini5 considered a simply supported beam with rotational viscous dampers attached to its pin connected ends. The beam is traversed by a constant moving force, and its deflection is determined by means of the complex mode superposition method. When modeling the high speed railway network system, a modified design is used where the simply supported beam is replaced by a beam sitting on an elastic foundation. The dynamic analysis of such systems under moving loads was conducted by Thambiratnam and Zhuge,6 Lin7 and Dimitrovová.8 Lou9 performed the dynamic analysis of a rail and bridge system under static and moving loads using the FEM. Interactions between the train, track and bridge are carefully modeled, and the beam deflection is obtained by two different approaches. In the first, it is directly computed from the beam elements shape functions and in the second, it is obtained using the modal analysis method.

The tremor resulting from the moving loads threatens the integrity of the supporting structure and reduces the passenger comfort level. Several techniques were proposed to attenuate this unwanted vibration by for example carefully designing the shape of the structure or by installing vibration absorbers. The beam shape optimization problem for moving loads has been explored by Hino et al.10 and, Bryant and Heinlein.11 Vibration absorbers have been successfully used for systems under stationary excitations. For example, Jalili and Esmailzadeh12 used a double-ended cantilever beam with adjustable lumped masses for vibration reduction in a harmonically forced single degree of freedom system. The first three beam modes are used to model the absorber which is tuned by properly adjusting the masses positions on the beam. Parametric stability is ensured through a constraint equation. Yang et al.,13 attached an aluminum beam with lumped masses to the tip of a cantilever steel beam subjected to random and harmonic excitations. The masses and their positions on the aluminum beam are carefully chosen to properly tune the absorber. An experimental setup is built to validate the absorber effectiveness. The use of the vibration absorber for moving loads was also studied in the literature. Chen and Chen14 proposed a design of vibration absorbers for single and multi-span simply supported beams subjected to constant and harmonic moving loads. The absorbers tuning is based on the first mode of the system. The system model is obtained using the FEM and the first few modes are used in the determination of the beam dynamic displacement. An example of a three equal span elevated railways subjected to the Japanese SKS train is considered. Yau15 proposed a string type vibration absorber for beams under repetitive traveling loads. The absorber consists of a stretched string and a distributed spring mass damper. The traveling loads are modeled as harmonic loading, and the optimal absorber parameters are obtained analytically using the invariant points method. Younesian et al.16 determined the optimal parameters of a tuned mass damper for vibration suppression of beams subjected to moving loads. The beam is modeled using its first dominant mode and the objective is the root mean square of the beam deflection during the load passage. The sequential quadratic programming method was used in the calculation of the optimal parameters. Wu17 used the classical absorber and a modified absorber model which included the spring inertia effects to reduce the displacement of a simply supported beam subjected to a moving load. The beam was modeled by means of the FEM and the optimal absorber parameters were obtained by tuning the absorber to the first beam mode. In a recent work by Samani and Pellicano,18 a linear and a nonlinear absorber were used for vibration suppression in a simply supported beam subjected to a constant moving load. The optimal absorber parameters were obtained numerically for two objective functions. The first is the minimization of the beam displacement and the second is the maximization of the energy dissipated in the absorber.

Common examples of structures traversed by moving dynamic excitations are, vehicles traveling on short or long suspended bridges, trains on railway tracks and railway bridges, and loads moving on cranes racks. The system model will include the dynamics of both the supporting structure and the moving object. For example, a moving vehicle can be modeled as a mass spring damper to include the vehicle inertia and bouncing effects. If the model is to be further enhanced, the pitch effect can be included. Furthermore, more degrees of freedom can be added to include the passengers' dynamics. As for the fixed supporting structure, it is modeled using the classical FEM, or simply assumed to behave as piecewise connected beams. When the size and mass of the moving object is small compared to those of the supporting structure, the moving object can be modeled as a constant moving load. In this work, the problem of a simply supported beam traversed by a constant moving load is considered. A linear vibration absorber is used to minimize the maximum of the beam displacement. The main contribution of this work stems from the fact that the optimal parameters are generic and can be used for the design of absorbers for beams with any geometric and material properties traversed by loads with any speeds. Furthermore, it is shown that the optimal absorber is undamped and should be attached at a fixed location independent of the mass ratio of the system and damping ratio of the beam. In the next section, the equation of motion of the system is derived in terms of dimensionless parameters. The optimal absorber parameters are calculated numerically for a range of the mass and modal damping ratios in the third section. In the fourth section, the dimensionless results are fitted to a second-order polynomial yielding an approximate analytical solution to the problem. In the same section, the numerical example in Samani and Pellicano18 is reconsidered for comparison. Concluding remarks and directions for future works are given in the last section.

sec.title: Equation of motion
sec.p:
The schematic of a simply supported beam with a linear absorber traversed by a moving load is shown in Figure 1. Where, z denotes the absorber displacement and w(x, t) the transverse beam displacement at a given spatial position x and time t. ρ and E are the beam density and modulus of elasticity, respectively, and A and I are the beam cross-sectional area and its second moment of inetia, respectively. P is a constant load moving at a constant speed v. The absorber parameters are m, k and c, and xa is its position on the beam. Assuming the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory, the partial governing beam equation of motion and the absorber equation of motion can be written as follows (1)ρAw··(x,t)+EIw″″(x,t)+[k(w(x,t)-z(t)) +c(w·(x,t)-z·(t))]δ(x-xa)=Pδ(x-vt)h(L-vt)mz··(t)+k(z(t)-w(xa,t))+c(z·(t)-w·(xa,t))=0 In equation (1), δ and h denote the dirac delta and heaviside functions, respectively. Let s = x/L and τ = vt/L denote the dimensionless spatial position and time, respectively. The equations of motion can be written in terms of s and τ as follows (2)ρAv2L2w··(s,τ)+EIL4w″″(s,τ)+[kL(w(s,τ)-z(τ)) +cvL2(w·(s,τ)-z·(τ))]δ(s-sa)=PLδ(s-τ)h(1-τ)mv2L2z··(τ)+k(z(τ)-w(sa,τ))+cvL(z·(τ)-w·(sa,τ))=0 Now, let u(s, τ) = w(s, τ)/(PL3/48EI) and y(τ) = z(τ)/(PL3/48EI) denote the dimensionless beam and absorber displacements, respectively. Using these dimensionless parameters, equation (2) takes the form (3)ρAv2L2EIu··(s,τ)+u″″(s,τ)+[kL3EI(u(s,τ)-y(τ)) +cvL2EI(u·(s,τ)-y·(τ))]δ(s-sa)=48δ(s-τ)h(1-τ)mv2L2y··(τ)+k(y(τ)-u(sa,τ))+cvL(y·(τ)-u·(sa,τ))=0 Finally, the material and geometric parameters are grouped into the below four dimensionless parameters (4)Ω1=π2vLEIρA, μ=mρALλ=kL3EI, σ=cvL2EI Ω1 encompasses all material and geometric properties of the beam including the speed of motion of P. The mass ratio μ is the ratio of the absorber mass to the beam mass. The remaining two parameters, namely λ and σ which are referred to as the stiffness and damping ratios, are directly related to the absorber stiffness and damping constants, respectively. Given the beam material and geometric properties, and for a given absorber mass, the optimal absorber location xaopt, absorber stiffness kopt and damping constant copt are calculated numerically such that the maximum beam displacement is minimized ∀v > 0. Using the dimensionless parameters, the problem reduces to, for a given μ, the optimal absorber location saopt, the optimal stiffness ratio λopt and the optimal damping ratio σopt are determined such that the maximum beam displacement is minimized ∀Ω1 > 0. Using the dimensionless parameters and after simplifications, the equation of the motion of the system reduces to (5)π4Ω12u··(s,τ)+u″″(s,τ)+[λ(u(s,τ)-y(τ))+σ(u·(s,τ) -y·(τ))] δ(s-sa)=48δ(s-τ)h(1-τ)y··(τ)+λΩ12π4μ(y(τ)-u(sa,τ))+σΩ12π4μ(y·(τ)-u·(sa,τ))=0 Figure 1.
A simply supported beam with a linear absorber traversed by a moving load.

sec.title: Optimal absorber parameters
sec.p:
The optimization problem is solved numerically since an analytical solution is not possible. The modal superposition method is used to solve equation (5). Using the first n modes of the beam, the transverse beam displacement is approximated as (6)u(s,τ)=∑i=1nφi(s)ηi(τ), φi(s)=2π2Ω1sin(iπs) where, ηi(τ) and ϕi(s) are the ith dimensionless modal displacement and normalized mode shape. Assuming proportional modal damping with ζi being the ith modal damping ratio, equation (5) is written in modal space as follows (7)ηi··(τ)+2i2ζiΩ1ηi·(τ)+i4Ω12ηi(τ)+λ[∑j=1n2Ω12π4sin(iπsa) ×sin(jπsa)ηj(τ)-2Ω1π2sin(iπsa)y(τ)]+σ[∑j=1n2Ω12π4 ×sin(iπsa)sin(jπsa)η·j(τ)-2Ω1π2sin(iπsa)y·(τ)] =482Ω1π2sin(iπτ)h(1-τ)y··(τ)+λΩ12π4μ[y(τ)-∑j=1n2Ω1π2sin(jπsa)ηj(τ)] +σΩ12π4μ[y·(τ)-∑j=1n2Ω1π2sin(jπsa)η·j(τ)]=0 The problem is solved using a direct search optimization method based on the Nelder–Mead simplex method. During the problem resolution, the fourth-order Runge–Kutta algorithm which is a numerical integration scheme is used to solve equation (7), assuming zero initial conditions. When searching for the maximum of u(s, τ), i.e. Umax, s is varied from 0 to 1 to cover the whole beam span and τ is varied from 0 to 12 to ensure that Umax is enclosed in the search region. The first ten modes are assumed to completely describe the beam motion, i.e. n = 10. It is assumed that the beam has equal modal damping ratios, i.e. ζ1 = ζ2 = … = ζn = ζ. The optimal solutions are obtained for the following modal damping ratios, ζ = 0.005, 0.01, 0.015, 0.02, 0.025, 0.03. The mass ratio is varied from only 0.03 to 0.07 to reduce the beam static deflection resulting from the attachment of the absorber. It is found that ∀μ ∈ [0.03 0.07] and ∀ζ ∈ [0.005 0.03], the optimal damping ratio σopt = 0 and saopt = 0.55. This physically means that the optimal absorber is an undamped absorber which should be attached at a location saopt = 0.55. The optimal stiffness ratio λopt is calculated and plotted in Figure 2 along with Umax. Figure 2.
Plots of: (a) the optimal stiffness ratio λopt and (b) Umax.

In Figure 3, examples are considered for ζ = 0.005 and 0.01. For each modal damping case, Umax is plotted versus 1/Ω1 for several values of the mass ratio μ including μ = 0.0 which corresponds to the maximum deflection of the bare beam. In these figures, Umax is plotted versus 1/Ω1 because Ω1 is inversely proportional to the speed v of the moving load. This results in Umax curves with trends similar to those found in the literature since classically the maximum displacement is plotted versus v. The absorber is observed as expected to reduce the maximum beam displacement and its effectiveness increases with the increasing of μ. Figure 3.
Plots of Umax versus 1/Ω1 for (a) ζ = 0.005 and (b) ζ = 0.01, for various mass ratios.

sec.title: Approximate analytical model
sec.p:
The optimal damping ratio λopt which was obtained numerically in the previous section and plotted in a two-dimensional plot in Figure 2(a), is now plotted in a three-dimensional plot versus both μ and ζ as shown in Figure 4(a). Similarly, Umax is plotted in Figure 4(b). In these plots, each point depicts the numerical solution obtained for a given (μ, ζ) pair. These points are observed to follow a well behaved pattern and therefore they are curve fitted with a quadratic curve in μ and ζ. The approximate analytical models are written as follows (8)λopt=0.0246-7.8ζ+180μ-410.2ζμ +220ζ2-389.3μ2Umax=1.737-2.524ζ-2.3μ+6.834ζμ +3.21ζ2+2.93μ2 The analytical expression of λopt in equation (8) is shown to have a maximum error of 0.39% with the numerical values of λopt depicted by the points in Figure 4(a). Similarly, the Umax analytical model has a maximum error of 0.029%. This concludes the study of a linear vibration absorber attached to a beam subjected to a constant moving load. For a given ζ and μ, the optimal absorber is undamped and should be attached at a position corresponding to s = 0.55. The absorber stiffness and the corresponding maximum beam displacement can be calculated from the analytical expressions in equation (8). These results are generic and can be used for simply supported beams with any material and geometric properties. Figure 4.
Three-dimensional plots of: (a) λopt and (b) Umax versus ζ and μ. The points denote the numerical solutions and the surfaces denote the quadratic curves fitted to the points.

The results obtained are compared to the numerical example which was considered in Samani and Pellicano.18 In this example, the material and geometric beam properties are E = 206.8 GPa, ρ = 7820 kg/m3, A = 0.03 × 0.03 m2 and L = 4 m. The force, absorber mass and modal damping ratio are, P = 9.8 N, m = 1.4076 kg and ζ = 0.01, respectively. The authors stated that the optimal damping constant is equal to zero but to avoid numerical problems they used c = 0.1 Ns/m. The optimal results are: the absorber location xaopt = 0.55L and the absorber stiffness kopt = 1795 N/m. The resultant maximum beam deflection is 1.5054 m which occurs at xmax = 0.53L. Samani and Pellicano18 noted that xaopt = 0.55L is insensitive to the system parameters. Finally, it is important to note that the optimal results are calculated with the aim of minimizing the beam deflection at a constant speed of v = 21.6 m/s at which the undamped bare beam experiences a maximum. For this numerical example, ζ = 0.01 and μ = 0.05. The dimensionless optimal solutions obtained in this work are: saopt = 0.55, λopt = 7.7892 and Umax = 1.6082 which are calculated numerically and, λopt = 7.7902 and Umax = 1.6078 obtained using equation (8). The error between the numerically and analytically calculated values of λopt and Umax is negligible. The optimal absorber stiffness is calculated using equation (4) as kopt = 1699.13 N/m and the corresponding dimensional maximum beam displacement is ymax = 1.505 mm. The maximum of the beam displacement occurs at smax = 0.528 and Ω1max = 5.2903, yielding vmax = 20.77 m/s. These results closely match those in Samani and Pellicano18 except for the 5.65% discrepancy between the kopt = 1699.13 N/m calculated in this work and that, kopt = 1795 N/m, obtained in Samani and Pellicano.18 This might stem from the fact that in Samani and Pellicano18 the absorber damping is not zero and the objective function is minimized at a constant load speed (v = 21.6 m/s). In this work, the optimal damping ratio is zero and the objective function is minimized for all load speeds, i.e. ∀Ω1 > 0.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
The optimal design of a linear vibration absorber for vibration reduction in simply supported beams subjected to constant moving loads is considered. The objective is the minimization of the maximum beam displacement. The problem is formulated in terms of dimensionless parameters. It is shown that the optimal absorber is undamped and its position corresponds to sa = 0.55 irrespective of the system geometric and material properties. For a range of the modal damping and mass ratios, the optimal stiffness ratio is calculated numerically. An analytical model is obtained by curve fitting the numerical results to a second-order polynomial. The analytical model proved to closely match the numerical results with a maximum error of 0.39%. This model is validated through comparison with a numerical example which was considered in the literature. Practically, the optimal absorber design for a structure traversed by moving loads, can be achieved as follows:
An adequate absorber mass should be chosen to avoid large static deflections.
The optimal absorber is undamped, i.e. consists of only a mass and spring element. Therefore, no damping element is needed.
The absorber stiffness is calculated from the analytical expression in equation (8).
It should be attached at a position 55% the structure span irrespective of all parameters. In this work, the moving force is assumed to be constant and its dynamic effects are neglected. Future works will include the study of beams subjected to moving masses or even moving dynamic systems.
